content: The "Coastal Restoration Tax Credit Act of 2005" may be cited as the Coastal Restoration Tax Credit Act. It introduces a credit for expenses incurred in restoring and protecting coastal lands under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The Coastal Restoration Tax Credit Act of 2005 allows a tax credit for qualified expenditures incurred by taxpayers for the taxable year, with a maximum credit limit of $2,000,000. The credit is subject to limitations based on the taxpayer's tax liability and other allowable credits. Qualified expenditures are defined as expenses related to coastal restoration and protection. The Coastal Restoration Tax Credit Act of 2005 allows a tax credit for qualified expenditures on approved projects to restore or protect coastal lands in the US. Excess credit can be carried forward or backward to future or past taxable years. Excess credit can be carried back for preceding taxable years, with specific rules for the number of years allowed for carryback. The basis of property for which a credit is allowable shall be reduced by the amount of the credit. No double benefit is allowed for deductions or credits, and the credit amount may be reduced for any federal, state, or local grants received. The Coastal Restoration Tax Credit Act of 2005 allows a tax credit for qualified expenditures on approved projects to restore or protect coastal lands in the US. The basis of property for which a credit is allowable shall be reduced by the amount of any Federal, State, or local grant or other assistance received by the taxpayer during such taxable year or any prior taxable year which was used to make qualified expenditures and which was not included in the gross income of such taxpayer. The amendments made by the Coastal Restoration Tax Credit Act of 2005 apply to taxable years beginning after December 31, 2004.
